title.narrative: Increasing safe and equitable access to formal education for crisis-affected children in Syria

description.narrative: For more than seven years children have been the direct targets of violence, witnessed violence, or committed violent acts themselves. As per the last estimations, 5.3 million children remain in need of some type of humanitarian assistance [HNO, 2018]. The short and long-term impacts of these experiences differ for each child and are influenced by a range of resilience and vulnerability factors. Such factors can include a child’s age, their care arrangements, and any previous exposure to violence. Researches also revealing the long-term neurological impacts of children’s repeated exposure to violence, which can lead to toxic stress. To aggravate the contextual situation, there are 5.8 million school-aged children and youth from pre-school to secondary age, and over 300,000 education personnel, in need of sectoral-humanitarian assistance. The project aims at increasing the access to a protective, safe, and conducing learning environment among crisis-affected children and teachers in three formal elementary schools (Arabic-curricula) of Hassakeh-city. It builds on a two-pronged strategy. The first pillar seeks to provide protective and safe learning environments through small-scale rehabilitation, including gender-sensitive WASH facilities, combined with the provision of learning supplies. The second pillar works in parallel and aims at ensuring conducive learning environments through capacity building of teachers on pyscho-social support. Schools and teachers can facilitate children’s recovery from trauma, having a significant impact on their student’s well-being. The purpose of the psychosocial component of the project essentially, is enhancing the skills and competencies of teachers to support the psychosocial recovery of crisis -affected children to understand, identify and refer children with symptoms of various psychological and behavioral problems to trauma therapy. This effort is crucial to allow longer-term progamming. As outcome, the project seeks to increase access to protective, safe, and conducing learning environments for 12,060 crisis-affected children and 300 teachers in Hassakeh. Finally, the project will be implemented directly by AAH, which has the capacity to start the implementation immediately, counting on the full-access to the facilities targeted.
